frame.name: Size
frame.definition:
<def-root>The size of an <fen>Entity</fen> is assessed in terms of the <fen>Degree</fen> by which it deviates from the norm. The size generally refers to the amount of three-dimensional space that is occupied by the <fen>Entity</fen>, not primarily to its weight, density, or length, which is why it is peculiar to refer to a bullet as "large", even if it is heavy, unless it actually has larger dimensions than usual, or to a rope as "big", even if it is long, unless its other, cross-sectional dimensions are also significant.
<ex>I own a <fex name="Degree">very</fex> <t>small</t> <fex name="Entity">home</fex>.</ex> <ex>Where is my <t>little</t> <fex name="Entity">notebook</fex>?</ex> <ex><fex name="Entity">That dog</fex> is <t>huge</t>!</ex> <ex></ex>
There are an enormous number of productive metaphors that involve this frame as the source domain; two of the most frequent metaphors come from the target domains of quantity/amount and importance.
<ex>He gave me a <t>small</t> <fex name="Entity">sum of money</fex>.</ex> <ex>The novel was a <t>substantial</t> <fex name="Entity">achievement</fex>.</ex> <ex></ex>
Subcases of the quantity/amount and importance metaphors are also prominent. These involve cases describing the extent of an action's, event's, or person's effect ("his influence on her work was massive"), as well as those related to events ("big party"), similarity ("gigantic difference"), communication ("giant misunderstanding"), and emotions ("great joy", "little joys").
Other productive metaphors include those dealing with groups (in terms of their number of members, net worth, importance to the economy, i.e. "giant electronics company") and those describing sound volume ("in a tiny voice", "the enormous thundering of her heart"). <ex></ex>
The target domain of fame, by contrast, occurs in a non-productive metaphor, found especially with big.a and huge.a. Maturity and age also occur in non-productive metaphors ("big boy", "little baby").</def-root>

FE.name: Entity
FE.definition:
<def-root>The thing whose size is being considered.
<ex>I had a <t>big</t> <fex name="Entity">dinner</fex>.</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Degree
FE.definition:
<def-root>The extent to which the size of the Entity deviates from the norm.
<ex>I had a <fex name="Degree">really</fex> <t>big</t> dinner.</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Standard
FE.definition:
<def-root>The size of the <fen>Entity</fen> may be compared to the size of a <fen>Standard</fen>.
<ex>You 're <t>tall</t> <fex name="Standard">for a Swede</fex>.</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Subregion
FE.definition: <def-root>This FE denotes a specific subregion being sized.</def-root>

FE.name: Dimension
FE.definition:
<def-root>The feature of an (actual or possible) <fen>Entity</fen> that is measured. In literal examples, it essentially must be size, or a word equivalent to size such as bulk.
<ex>The particles were <t>smaller</t> <fex name="Dimension">in size</fex> than expected .</ex> <ex>Her <fex name="">huge</fex> <fex name="Dimension">girth</fex> interfered with normal daily activities .</ex> <ex>Chickens hardly have an <t>immense</t> <fex name="Dimension">intellect</fex> .</ex></def-root>
